p: Model-based surveillance optimization may require substantial computing effort, particularly since it almost always involves a spatial dimension [ 43]. Various mathematical modeling and programming methods (e.g. mixed-integer programming [ 23, 50, 60]), facilitated by increasingly efficient optimization software, have made it possible to compute optimal solutions in a reasonable amount of time, usually a matter of hours [ 43]. This is true even though many optimization studies involving invasive species surveillance have added complexity by incorporating uncertainty in one or more parameters, such as dispersal [ 23, 50, 55, 57, 60], the probability of detection [ 67] or the current invasion extent [ 49].
